title: Eukaryotic Cell Compartmentalisation
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Exploration of eukaryotic cell structures with focus on the true nucleus, nuclear envelope, nucleolus, 80S ribosomes, and the advantages of compartmentalisation.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the structure of the nucleus (double membrane, pores, nucleolus) and contrast it with the prokaryotic nucleoid.
Students can distinguish between free and bound ribosomes (80S) and relate their location to protein destination.
Students can compare prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells using at least four structural differences.

syllabusLinks.inquiryQuestion: IQ1: What distinguishes one cell from another?

successCriteria: I can label the nucleus, nuclear envelope, and nucleolus on a diagram.
I can explain why the nucleus is described as membrane-bound while the nucleoid is not.
I can state two advantages of having membrane-bound organelles (compartmentalisation).

engagementHook.title: The Control Centre
engagementHook.content: Show an image of a hospital with separate wards vs. a warehouse. 'Prokaryotes are like a warehouse—everything happens in one open space. Eukaryotes are like a modern hospital with specialised wards (organelles). The CEO (DNA) is locked in the executive suite (nucleus). Today we explore that executive suite and why compartmentalisation matters.'

keyConcepts.definition: Surrounded by a double membrane (nuclear envelope) with pores that control what enters and exits. Contains linear chromosomes and the nucleolus (where ribosomes are made).
Dense region inside the nucleus where ribosomal RNA is produced and ribosomal subunits are assembled (not membrane-bound itself).
Larger than prokaryotic ribosomes (60S and 40S subunits). Found free in cytoplasm (make proteins for cell use) or bound to endoplasmic reticulum (make proteins for export).
Membrane-bound organelles allow different chemical reactions to occur in separate areas, increasing efficiency and organisation.
Generally larger (10–100 µm) than prokaryotic cells (1–10 µm).

misconceptions.misconception: The nucleolus is a membrane-bound organelle inside the nucleus
misconceptions.correction: Nucleolus is a dense region/area, not a separate membrane-bound structure. Analogy: Nucleus is a stadium; nucleolus is the pitch in the centre.

misconceptions.misconception: Eukaryotic cells are just bigger prokaryotes with a nucleus added
misconceptions.correction: Emphasise multiple differences (membrane-bound organelles, different ribosomes, linear DNA, different cell walls).

misconceptions.misconception: All eukaryotic cells have cell walls
misconceptions.correction: Only plants (cellulose), fungi (chitin), and some protists have walls. Animal cells do not.

contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: What passes through the nuclear pores? (RNA, proteins, but DNA stays inside.)

contentSections.title: 80S Ribosomes and Protein Synthesis
contentSections.content: 80S ribosomes made of 60S and 40S subunits. Free ribosomes make proteins for use inside the cell. Bound ribosomes (attached to ER) make proteins for export or insertion into membranes.
contentSections.example: Pancreatic cells have many bound ribosomes to make digestive enzymes for export.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Would a cell producing insulin for export have many free or bound ribosomes? Why?

activities.title: Prokaryote or Eukaryote?
activities.description: Complete the sentences by choosing the correct cell type.
activities.learningObjective: Sort features into prokaryotic or eukaryotic.
activities.text: Cells with a nucleoid region are [[prokaryotic]]. Cells with a true membrane-bound nucleus are [[eukaryotic]]. 70S ribosomes are found in [[prokaryotic]] cells, while 80S ribosomes are found in [[eukaryotic]] cells. Circular DNA is characteristic of [[prokaryotic]] cells, whereas linear DNA is found in [[eukaryotic]] cells.

multipleChoice.question: Which feature is unique to eukaryotic cells?
multipleChoice.rationale: Both cell types have DNA, ribosomes, and can have cell walls. Only eukaryotes have a membrane-bound nucleus.

multipleChoice.question: The nucleolus is responsible for:
options: Separating the nucleus from the cytoplasm
Producing ribosomal RNA and assembling ribosomes
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Producing ribosomal RNA and assembling ribosomes
multipleChoice.rationale: Tests nucleolus function vs other nuclear components. The envelope separates nucleus from cytoplasm; chromatin stores genetic info; pores transport proteins.

multipleChoice.question: Compared to prokaryotic ribosomes, eukaryotic ribosomes are:
multipleChoice.rationale: Reinforces 70S vs 80S distinction from Lessons 1-2. Prokaryotes have smaller 70S ribosomes; eukaryotes have larger 80S ribosomes.

shortAnswer.question: Compare the nucleoid region of a prokaryotic cell with the nucleus of a eukaryotic cell. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Nucleoid has no membrane; nucleus has double membrane with pores
1 mark: Nucleoid has circular DNA; nucleus contains linear DNA/chromosomes
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying nucleoid has 'no DNA' or confusing sizes.

shortAnswer.question: Explain one advantage of having membrane-bound organelles in eukaryotic cells. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Different chemical reactions can occur in separate compartments/isolated environments
1 mark: Allows specialisation of function/increases efficiency/prevents incompatible reactions mixing
shortAnswer.example: Digestive enzymes in lysosomes kept separate from cytoplasm to prevent self-damage.

definitions: Eukaryotic cells have a true nucleus surrounded by a double membrane with pores.
Eukaryotic DNA is linear and associated with proteins (histones).
The nucleolus is inside the nucleus and makes ribosomes.
keyPoints: Nuclear envelope = double membrane with pores for transport
Nucleolus = dense region, NOT membrane-bound, makes rRNA and ribosome subunits
Free ribosomes make proteins for cell use; bound ribosomes make proteins for export
Compartmentalisation allows efficient, specialised chemical reactions
diagrams: Labelled diagram of nucleus showing envelope, pores, nucleolus, chromatin

shortAnswer: The nucleoid region of a prokaryotic cell has no surrounding membrane and contains circular DNA. In contrast, the nucleus of a eukaryotic cell is surrounded by a double membrane with pores that control transport, and it contains linear DNA organised into chromosomes.

Membrane-bound organelles allow different chemical reactions to occur in separate, isolated compartments. This prevents incompatible reactions from mixing and allows each organelle to specialise in particular functions, increasing the efficiency of cellular processes. For example, digestive enzymes are kept inside lysosomes to prevent damage to the cytoplasm.
